When it is time to cook at home, we usually prepare more than one meal at a time. Our 2 years old keeps us really busy! So we normally use more than one spatula. Utensil dishes are designed just for one spatula. Here I present my solution, a triple utensil holder. It is designed with 3 separate containers that can be extracted separately. If you only use one, you just have to clean that one and not the entire holder.
If you only cook for yourself, you can always use the other containers for storage. https://youtu.be/2zcfNx40GNk I hope you enjoy it and find it useful. Do you like it? Did you make one? Can you improve the design? All feedback will be appreciated. You can use the comments section. Thanks!!
The main container and the inner ones need support structures. The lids can be printed without problems. Take a look to the overview picture for dimensions, material and print time.

Every Kitchen needs more cheese. Here is a simple and sturdy cheese press that is 100% printable. This site has the other required material for making all kinds of cheeses.
http://www.culturesforhealth.com/cheese-making.html I recommend you use high infill and 4-8 shells for all components. This will take anywhere from 60-120 hours to make but in the end will save you a ton when considering the price of a real press. Will make up to a 2 lb wheel. Enjoy!

title: Cable Clip - Wire Organizer - USB / Phone

description.text:
This is a small clip that I designed to keep my USB cables nice and neat.   
So far, it works like a charm on every cable I've used it on. You can scale it up or down depending on your cable length but this size works for most USB cables (anywhere from 4 inches to 3 feet).   
Check the "Instructions" section for print suggestions.

I actually printed this in PLA but I would suggest using ABS since it's more flexible. I recommend using an extruder-mounted fan to cool the plastic as it is printed. This will give a much nicer overhang. My print settings for PLA were:
Infill: 50%
Number of Shells: 1
Layer Height: 0.25mm
Temperature: 208 C
Build Plate Temperature: 76 C
Speed while Extruding: 80
Speed while Traveling: 100

author: nerd4mario

description.text:
A small circuit to add a second fan to your RAMPS 1.4 controller. For instance :
  • the first fan is wired to D9 and cools down the print
  • the second fan is wired to the fan extender and cools down the printing head
    • The schematic is the same as on RAMPS board (for D8 to D10). A LED indicates when the fan is running.

THE CIRCUIT The files can be read with Eagle 7 free version (http://www.cadsoftusa.com/) Print the circuit on single-sided PCB, the parts needed are :
  • R1 : 10 ohms, SMD 1206
  • R2 : 100 Kohms, SMD 1206
  • R3 : 1800 ohms, SMD 1206
  • LED1 : SMD LED (red)
  • T1 : BSP126 (or an other N-MOSFET )
  • JP1, JP2 : 2.54mm connectors
    • You can add a capacitor between +12V and GND ( 100nF ) , solder it directly on JP1, below the PCB. WIRING First you have to solder on RAMPS board a 2-pin connector (+12V) and a 3-pin connector (Servo connector) as shown in the drawing. Then make a Y cable between +12V, the servo connector and JP1 on the PCB (see drawing). Be careful when you connect this cable on RAMPS board, it will make a short circuit if put in the wrong way. SOFTWARE I use this fan extender to cool down the printing head. To do this, in Marlin software, edit configuration_adv.h like this : #define EXTRUDER_0_AUTO_FAN_PIN 4 #define EXTRUDER_AUTO_FAN_TEMPERATURE 50 #define EXTRUDER_AUTO_FAN_SPEED 255 // == full speed and reprogram the firmware.

comments.text:
For PLA cooling with Marlin Firmware I think it's better to wire the fan on D9 (on the RAMPS board), the GCODE is M106/M107 to start/stop the fan.
Then you can use this thing for a second fan mounted on the hot end to prevent the filament from melting above the top of the hot end.

remixed_from.author: AndrewBCN
remixed_from.title: Open Hardware Knurled Knob for M6 Nut

title: Delta-Pi redesigned top clamp and idler assembly with tensioner

description.text:
The Delta-Pi motor mounts allow the stepper's position to be adjusted vertically by a few mm, thereby adjusting the GT2 belt tension, however this is far from practical since the steppers are mounted under the base. Once the printer is assembled and running it is highly unlikely that it can be disassembled / decommissioned for such trivial maintenance as adding a little bit of tension to one of the GT2 belts.  
I started thinking about this a couple of weeks ago and this week I began writing some OpenSCAD code for a much more convenient system to adjust the tension in the GT2 belt of each column using an extra assembly placed on top of the printer, whereby the belt tension is adjusted simply by turning a knurled knob.  
This is the result. It can be retrofitted to any Delta-Pi and I am going to use it for my modified Delta-Pi which I am still assembling.  
OpenSCAD sources are included so the thing can be further remixed.  
Update 18/03/2015: new OpenSCAD source file with option of simple microswitch or Makerbot-style mechanical endstop for the top clamp.

The idler assembly requires 1 x M3 20mm screw, 2 x M3 washer, 1 x M3 nyloc nut, 3 x M6 nut, 1 x M6 50mm hex screw .  
Note that this assembly reuses two of my previous designs, the knurled knob for M6 nut and the GT2 belt pulleys for 623zz bearings. Read the instructions in their respective pages to print these properly.  
Apart from that, I suggest to print these parts with 35% infill in PLA, that should be enough to get strong parts that won't break or delaminate. However, I recommend printing the idler lid and the tensioner with 50% or higher infill, as these parts are used in traction, not in compression.

title: Prusa i3 Bowden Extruder + Inductive Proximity Sensor + Radial Fan

description.text:
This is a simple proximity sensor mount add-on to the already great bowden hotend mount designed by Tech2c: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:547706. I really liked his design and couldn't find anything similar with a proximity mount, so I added my own as well as a radial fan mount with bi-directional fan duct. I have been printing with this at least a hundred hours with great results! This is installed and used on my Prusa i3 Wilson ts by mrice. Love the printer and would recommend it to anyone looking to build a prusa i3 variant.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:255605 The hotend I am using is a E3D V6 Jhead Hotend 1.75mm .4MM Nozzle Extrude http://r.ebay.com/gWXg4k off of eBay. Chinese knockoff i'm sure. The radial fan duct i used by ffleurey: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:151555 directs the air flow on two sides of the print with one fan. I don't like having any unnecessary weight added to the carriage. For those that don't know, "Inductive" proximity sensors only sense metals aka aluminum beds! I print directly to an aluminum heated bed sprayed with aqua net extra super hold. my prints stick very well. although i do miss printing directly on glass. I highly recommend watching this video about installing and wiring the proximity sensor. I also recommend watching Tom's other videos about 3d printing which are very informative. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EcGFLwj0pnA UPDATE 6/11/15 : V2 I moved the fan mount arm slightly to correct the hole alignment with the fan. I haven't printed it yet because I am using the first version which works with the aid of a zip tie instead of a screw. Additional info: Sensor Type: LJ12A3-4-Z/BX Inductive Proximity Sensor Switch NPN
Ebay has them for under $5 The hole for the prox sensor is 12 mm. The hardest thing to print is the radial fan duct. Print it separately in case it fails. It's a small print with thin walls and heavy bridging so make sure your printer is up to the task. Then simply glue it to the fan. All of the parts are printed in PLA. I have not had any issues of warping when printing with high temp materials. I have printed Nylon and ABS no problem. If you have any questions just shoot me a message! Printed with:
PLA 1.75mm
0.2mm layer height
40% infill
50mm/s print speed
no supports or rafts

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

wilson ts prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes: The Radial fan duct is the most difficult part to print. Make sure your printer is up to par in terms of bridging. I have printed a few of them, all without supports. You may have better luck with supports but i haven't tried yet. I also recommend printing the fan duct on its own so if it fails it wont affect other parts being printed. All other parts print without any issues. Good Luck and happy printing!

title: cradle for icom IC-A4 (battery charger)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Recently a my friend broke the plug to recharge his radio and asked me to fix the problem.
After verifying the irreparable nature of the radio I decided to buy a cradle on the internet but I do not find any.
So I designed and printed this thing. The cradle is formed by two parts: the body and bottom cap.
The body is composed in turn of two parts glued together because my 3D printer (and I think also that of many others) can not print large parts suspended in space.
I recovered the two contacts from underwire stiffening of the wipers, I then cut and curved so as to give them the correct form.
One tip I can give is to glue the two pieces with chemical glue before and after with hot glue.

title: Motor guard for Claghorn's direct drive mount

description.text:
Whether you have a menacing toddler or a cat that sees your printer as a habitat :D, this will cover your Y motor and shield the wires. A slit at the bottom allows for mounting a 40mm fan, and has a large inner chamber with slits for ventilating heat
EDIT: I added the front and rear anchors to mount the motor guard via M3 nuts. Whether they use M3x12 or M3x16 I forget, but it works great to the point I am doing this to all my machines. NOTE: You may need to flip the rear mount in your host software.

Print with support with a layer height no higher than .3951
All holes are intended for M3 socket caps. This guard will require a full acrylic panel running past the rear of the frame to anchor itself.
Mine was printed with a 8mm brim, E3D v5 with E3D Volcano .6mm nozzle. all available at http://www.filastruder.com/

A counter top item the will hold your eggs close to the stove or where ever you may need them.

Contertop challenge entry #CountertopChallenge
This is a box with ventilation to keep garlic or other food that needs airing to prevent moisture ruining it.
By printing with 22-25 filling and 0 mm top and base thickness, the cover and the sides of the box are printed as grills, so air can circulate. I developed this trick initially for electronic boxes, which also need ventilation. The letters and 3D garlic pieces add a nice touch to the attractive grill effect. You can experiment with the filling % for different grill effects. I love 3D printing!

I insist, the trick in printing this with grill sides and top is to print the box vertically and the cover flat, both with infill 22-25% (I use Cura for slicing), and 0 mm bottom and top thickness, plus a 2-4mm shell side wall.
Otherwise, I changed the filament colour when the printing reached the upper surface of the cover. The trick for changing filaments without problem is to elevate immediatly the extruder (so the heat does not ruin the area nea where it stopped), by inserting something to support the bridge. Then I free the motors, and change the filament. You feed manually a bit (until the colour changes) of filament, and when it is ready, you push X and Y reset to zero, then "resume" button to resume printing with the new colour.
Bow created based on Evendim bow from Champions of regnum. I added 2 versions low poly and smooth one. Hope you enjoy it :-)
Printed with 0.5 and no supports or infill

description.text: Bracket to mount an EZStruder (and stepper) to an OpenBeam extrusion at a 45 degree angle. The spacer is optional, depending on whether or not you need additional clearance for wheeled carriages. Print the bracket at with high infill due to the weight of the stepper motor. Note: The supplied STL is rendered for a large nema17 stepper (47mm), if your stepper is smaller, you will need to render your own version using the supplied OpenSCAD files (see instructions)

BOM:
  • 14/16mm M3 bolt
  • 20mm M3 bolt
  • 2x (without spacer) or 4x (with spacer) 8mm M3 bolt
  • 2x M3 nuts (when used with spacer)
    • If you want to render a new version using a different sized stepper motor, change nema_height in configuration.scad. Supported sizes are NemaShort (33mm), NemaMedium (39mm), NemaLong (47mm)

This is a modular shelf or rack for your spices etc. with a mount-in sound system for music streamed. This will add great music on every counter tops.
The length of the modules is 200mm (approx. 8 inch.) and are pushed on to the small brackets which are mounted on the wall. You can easily make your own customized 200 mm piece of shelf.
A small amplifier (2x 3W) is located in the small box in the middle of the rack and small full-range high quality 2.5" drivers are build into the two ends of the shelf.
You can connect to the speakers via the mini jack in the front and at the same time charge your smart phone via the USB connection. The system has to have 5 VDC to operate (f.ex. small USB charger) #CountertopChallenge

This is a cooling/warming plate in one. When set on cool it provides a cold surface for a few minutes, and when set to heat it has enough power to melt butter and keep things warm using only USB power. The bottom is a solid aluminum cylinder w/ a thin copper plate sandwiching a thermoelectric heat pump secured with thermal epoxy. Other metals can be substituted and will alter performance. Parts List
1) Aluminum Cylinder
2) Copper Plate
2) Thermoelectric heat pump
3) Rocker Switch
4) USB Cord
5) Thermal Epoxy
6) Silicone Caulk
7) 3d Printed Body

A terrifying predator from ancients time. Some mad scientists have found his DNA in a fossilized batch of flour and decided to bring him back to life helped with their 3D printer.
It's time to run !!!

WIP : The revival process need some improvements, the current DNA produce some weakness in the arms and the neck. Don't worry, thoses litlles problems don't make him less delicious. The scientists are working hard to make an even more terrifying Cookynausorus Rex soon ! I follow the Oogime sugar cookies recipe and tips [ http://www.oogime.com/ <= at the bottom of her page ] Cut all the parts, body and legs two time, use the patern stamps to make the reliefs (dont forget to flip one body and leg).
Cook everything.
Wait the cookies to be cold, and assemble them carefully with some frosting. (I use concentrated milk for this first, but real frosting should be better) And then, enjoy your Cookynausorus Rex with a cup of milk. ;)

A durable easy to use design that allows one to carry food, drink, utensil, and napkin with one hand in a single trip. No need to make multiple trips when taking food and drinks about. The Snack Attack features a bowl, a cup holder, and two side holders. The cup holder can hold a wide variety of glasses and cans. The bowl has ample room to fit foods and snacks that you desire. The side holders can also help you carry napkins and any utensils. The Snack Attack is designed with durable thick walls, printed from the Replicator 5th generation Makerbot using PLA food safe plastic, while being easy to hold for anyone with any size of hand. The Snack Attack will enhances your ability to transport your food and drinks with ease.

description.text:
(The Design of the Kitchen Ninja was created as a Part for the CountertopCallenge) With the Kitchen Ninja, cutting vegetables and fruits becomes much more efficent and fun!
There is a hole for waste and a hole for vegetables. You simply slide everything to
the side and it will fall into seperate boxes. With the furrow, the juice flows into the left or into the right
hole - depending on the way you insert the cutting board. All in all, you can store
4 boxes in it in case you want to cut more than one grocery. On the top, there are 2 slots to store kitchen
knives (or ninja swords respectively). The Kitchen Ninja is easy to wash. Except for the boxes you use you only need to wash the cutting board which you
can take off in one move. The boxes have rounded edges inside, the cutting board is only 15 mm thick - so
both can be washed by hand or in the dish washer. The Kitchen Ninja's design is based on 5 elements which are easy to print (+ the boxes). Their size is accustomed to
the makerbot printer. However, if requested, the Kitchen Ninja's size might be adjusted. The elements have a backlash of
up to 0.5 mm so they are easier to put together. The only overhangs are the slots of the cutting board. Once used, the Kitchen Ninja will become indispensible for the daily cooking routine. You can't buy the Kitchen Ninja! It's just for Print.

This lovely little container is super helpful for reminding you if you need sugar, flour, or any other sort of powdered food stuff!  
Powered off of a small microcontroller, 3 leds, a photoresistor, and a usb port, this beautifully designed container lights up red if you need more, and green if you are A-okay.

If there is a request, I will make a full fledged instructable about how to wire and place everything.  
If you have large hands then you need to print in pieces!

Reaching inside of the container to place the photo sensor and led might be a little tricky for some people, so I would suggest printing it in pieces I also had some trouble with creating a raft for the large piece, so I have included if the need arises. -Container should be printed at 100% infill
-Lid should be printed with support material, unless you are feeling badass You can find the code for the microcontroller in the downloads section I used the attiny85 based Trinket 7v from adafruit but there is no reason that it should not work with other microcontrollers

I modified an existing model, removing the pillars and floor piece. When printed at small size the peaks on the domes come out very thin and flimsy. I snapped them off my first print because they didn't come out well. Other than that the model easily prints with good detail.

I sliced using Slic3r with automatic support in rectilinear mode with a 3-layer raft. Printing with ABS on a glass bed, the raft seemed important to get the first layer to adhere well. The actual supports generated were minimal, mainly just a small pillar going up the center of the model to stabilize the top dome.

remixed_from.author: Jon_S
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Metal Plus Filament Spool Holder

title: Bearing for Printrbot Metal Plus Filament Spool Holder

description.text: Taking inspiration from BiZaRrO_John's bushings, I decided to add real rolling bearings to my Printrbot Metal Plus spool holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:675439) to make the filament feed really smooth. Starting with unitconversion's parametric ball bearing design, I tweaked it, optimized it for 3/16-inch balls, and added the cap piece that turns it in to a wheel for the PVC tubes.

Print four of these per spool (so eight if you have dual extruders). Load twenty 3/16-inch balls through the feed hole (while the inner ring is in place), and then place the cap piece over the top. The cap fit should be tight enough so that no glue is required. [Oh, don't forget to print my original spool holder first!] I believe you'll be able to find the ball bearings at any bike store, but I bought a pack of 144 for $5.45 from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000AO5KOW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1). I will actually need to buy some more, as I'll need 160 for my dual-extruder set up. I printed with 0.25mm layer height. If you need to tweak the fit for your particular printer the parameters you may want to adjust in the OpenSCAD model are: ball_spacing_ratio - clearance around the balls in the raceway [one of unitconversion's original variables]
cap_clearance - gap between outer wall of the bearing and the cap
bead_radius - (scroll down to find this variable) radius of the friction fit beads on the inside wall of the cap. These control the snugness of the cap press fit. This was my first time using OpenSCAD, so my apologies for the untidiness of the code. I was learning as I went along.

description.text: The Nom-Monster toast press makes breakfast a little more fun. It's simple to use, just push him into your bread before you toast it! I made this for the #CountertopChallenge . It's similar to a storm trooper one I made. The Nom-Monster was hand drawn, scanned, converted to DXF with a line tracer and then imported into Sketchup and re-worked. This is a proof of concept only. It needs improvements before you could use it on your toast (thicker walls and cleaner faces). It turns out it's harder than I thought to convert a hand drawn image to a 3D printable object, even with hours of work. If you want a toast press you can print and use today. Go for my Storm Trooper toast press. This is a proof of concept only. It needs improvements before you could use it on your toast (thicker walls and cleaner faces) Sample Video of how a toast press works: http://youtu.be/VCwYxKiTy0Q Sample video of nom monster coming soon!

description.text: This wall and counter top planter is ideal for herbs and spices. Nothing is better then having fresh ingredients at your fingertips in the kitchen. This is our next entry for the #CountertopChallenge. We hope you enjoy it, and the harvest it brings.

title: 6 Plant Modular Herb and Spice Planter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This modular spice and herb planter is another way to cultivate your own kitchen garden. This is our next entry for the #CountertopChallenge. With this design, you can stack planter stands and planters to achieve a terraced garden in your kitchen as big as you like.  The planters are available in two styles, one with with drain holes and one without. The drain holes will dispense excess water into the planter underneath, of it placed at the edge of a sink, into the sink.

Print with 10% infill and 3 shells. We recommend sealing this before use. We also recommend printing the planter stand with brims, and the planters with helper disks around the parameter to prevent warping.   
It would be a good idea to place a piece of screen inside the planters covering the drain holes to prevent soil loss as well.   
Print out multiple stands and glue them together. Glue stand to the bottom of planter to raise to necessary height.

description.text: Printed on a DIY I3. Strong - reliable bookend.

Grow a tree with your 3D printer! Build your own custom fruit tree. Change it within seconds to have it fit to your latest fruits. Pieces snap together and the tree is stable. The fruits are hold in spirals that bend down and wrap around the fruit. It is customize able with different branches, trunk pieces, leaves and roots. Start small and let it grow higher.
Check out how it works in this animation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pByeTKZoU_U No support required and it also prints with small 120x120mm printer. You could also go crazy with colors with just a single extruder printer. You can of course also use it to hold other things then just fruits. Entered in the Countertop Challenge, voting here: https://t.co/EhBPfG1BCK [Update: Very slighlty increased the trunk connections tolerance. Because I tested it with a very high infill and it turned out that disconnecting is too hard with it. The updated version works now also fine with very high infill. If you like the lower tolerance version, they are in the Trunk-Pieces_Lower-Tolerance.zip now. If the new should be still a too low tolerance for printing with PLA let me know and make a extra version for that. I can't test PLA myself.]

No support required, ABS with raft recommended. (Raft at least for the branches when using ABS) ABS lets the spirals bend better and pieces connect easier. For a basic tree you need the following:
Trunk-Base.stl
Trunk-1xSlot.stl
Trunk-Crown.stl
Leave.stl x6
Crown-LeavesTop.stl
Branch-Normal.stl (or any other branch)
Root-Normal-Wavy.stl x6 (or any other root) Branches spiral sizes are the following:
Branch-Big: apples and oranges
Branch-Normal: Pears, big nectarines and small apples
Branch-Small: Peaches and kiwis
Branch-VerySmall: Prunes and strawberries Those fruits are just examples of sizes that fit best to give you an idea.
  • Not only the trunk length can be added on, the leaves as well. 9 leaves pieces connected in a loop build the magic bracelet of torment. There is a hidden case piece that can be put in the base piece. You can just hide stuff in there or use it to put more weight at the bottom which can be helpful when you are aiming very high. It also recommended to use at least the normal length roots for stability. If you wonder how high it can get: ca 3.5m with 1kg of filament which is much higher then most ceilings.

title: Macbook Magsafe 2 Adapter Cable Retainer Clip - Flexible Filament Ninjaflex

description.text:
My wife was constantly losing my Magsafe to Magsafe 2 adapter. So I printed a small retaining clip/strap to prevent any more lost adapters. When my wife uses my charger, she removes the Magsafe 2 adapter and uses the Magsafe connector in her 2011 Macbook. This retainer clip allows the the adapter to remain attached to the power cord, even when not in use.  
You must use a flexible filament like Ninjaflex for print and two nylon zipties to secure the printed object to the power cord. I used pink zipties in the photos for contrast.  
Special thanks to AKAMEDIASYSTEM for the original design.

description.text: This is a play stove top. The knobs do not turn and the personalized "TYLERTOP" label shown in the picture has been removed.

I created this for our bathroom to put sea salt hand scrub in by the sink. http://www.thekitchn.com/how-to-make-an-exfoliating-sea-salt-hand-scrub-projects-from-the-kitchen-213554 She picked up some when we were in Florida last Christmas so I thought this would be a nice change from the bowl its in now. I used the sea shell, smoothed it and reduced the mesh resolution considerably. I did some touchup work as well as altered the shape a bit to be deeper and more bowl like. I used the base from the nude woman thing and sank the shell into it. I reduced the mesh resolution here as well. I have included the Modo scene file in case you want to make mods to it.

Print each part individually and then use acetone or glue (as whats appropriate for whatever you printed it in) to attach the shell to the base.  
If you are using this for what I made it for, print it in something that the oil will not react with.  ABS seems to be ok so far but I only have a limited test time with it.  I suspect LayBrick would be too porous.

title: Convert Contour Rotating Mount to GoPro Rotating Mount

description.text:
Revised version with larger and correct number of teeth and slightly shorter arm to fit tighter.  
If you have one of the first generation Contour Rotating Mounts (thicker than the current rotating mount), you can disassemble it and replace the mount with this piece. then reassemble the mount.  
Contour's rotating mount has a LOCK button and firmly locks in the rotated angle. It is a flat surface Mount.   
The current rotating mounts are not meant to be disassembled and cannot be converted.  
IGES & SAT files included for modification.

author: spond550

description.text:
I wanted a Flynn's arcade sign to hang by my MAME cab. What I came up with has a multitude of uses. Use the Flynn's marquee I provide, or make your own marquee for this box (I provide the template). More designs are coming, and marquees are easily swapped by removing the bezel. A notch in the bottom accepts an optional tag, and the box itself can be printed either with or without screw hanger holes on the back.  
Additional marquees and improvements to the design are in the works, but is perfectly workable in it's current state.  
Light up your world with this awesome weekend project!

Descriptions of the STL files follow; Print the parts needed depending on your build: Marquee box:
marquee_box_hangers.stl - has screw hanging holes on the back for wall mounting
marquee_box_noholes.stl - has no holes, ideal for a desk or tabletop. Bezels:
marquee_bezel.stl - A clean bezel to retain the marquee sign
marquee_bezel_notched.stl - has a circular notch on one end to help accommodate a grommet or power socket Lastly, Arcade_one_piece_large.stl is an optional tag that can be attached to the notch in the bottom of the sign. Print it in black, and switch colors when the letters start printing. Signage consists of two parts, mask and diffuser:
FLYNNS mask and diffuser stl's are for the sign pictured, while marquee_blank_template.stl is a blank mask (or for dimensions on your own sign) and marquee_diffuser_blank.stl is a blank for a diffuser to be used with a mask of your own design. I used automotive LED strips to provide the lighting, and a 12v power brick to drive it. you can easily come up with your own lighting solution. Also, holes can be drilled in the box to accommodate plugs, wires, switches, etc. *Some additional notes on lighting (addendum as of 3/16/2015): I lined the interior of the box with aluminum foil tape (usually found at hardware stores in the plumbing section). This makes the interior reflective. You can also paint the inside white, or just use sheets of white paper. Using colored paper or paint will also color your reflected light as well. The LED strips were placed around the interior perimeter of the box, stuck to the interior walls where they meet the backplate.
Sometimes the LED's themselves will cause "hot spots", extra bright areas, which are visible through the diffuser. To make the illumination more consistent, you can use strips of paper, polyfill or thin packing foam directly in front of the LED's, in-between the LED strip and the marquee to diffuse these hot spots. Feel free to experiment and fine tune your setup to provide the best lighting effects. On the Flynn's Marquee: The diffuser snaps onto the mask over 3mm "pins". Note that you may need to ream the holes on the diffuser a little if it doesn't easily slip over the pins. Next, putting it on a light table or a window, color the diffuser as in the last two photos (the final one is a quality photo of an actual FLYNN'S neon sign). start on the back of the diffuser, using the mask as a template. once done, remove the diffuser form the mask, flip it around, and do the other side as well. To be "screen Correct", three sharpie markers in the following colors should be used: "Neon Yellow", "Neon Orange" and standard Orange" The center-most "neon tube" should be neon yellow, the next two out from that should be neon orange, and the outermost from those should be standard orange. The color is definitely noticeable, but when photographed, it all tends to just look orange. My pictures don't do it justice, it will look much cooler when viewed in-person. I also did another marquee using only standard orange, and while decent, using the tri-color method makes it pop, and is authentic to the signs used in the TRON films, as well as those in the actual arcades at Disney, and during the ComiCon viral campaign. Lastly, place the diffuser onto the mask, aligning it over the pins. I used a micro torch to quickly heat each pin, and pressed it down flat using the end of a bolt as a tool. This will rivet the diffuser onto the mask. Of course, you may also use glue. Feel free to use my blank templates to create your own signage, or you could have a marquee printed to the correct dimensions, mount to some thin glass or plexi, and use that instead. In conclusion, I have also included the SVG files I used in the making of for the Flynn's sign, as it's hard to get the logo correct, and the font is not freely available. By the way, this design maxes out my Rep2's build area on the X, so you may need to rescale everything to get it to print on smaller machines, but if you go bigger, I'd love to see the results!
Any questions, please ask. and definitely share your makes if you get good use out of this!

The body consists of four parts: a base, a central spindle, a top and a lid.  
Each herb or spice is then stored inside one of the pie segments that slot into place and can then be rotated to be selected for pouring.

This is a spring loaded sponge holder with an ability to wick using one hand. The idea is to have the dish soap bottle sitting vertically and to feed through the bottom opening in the sponge holder. By pushing in the sponge with one hand will allow the transfer of soap to the sponge.
I came up with this design when i was doing ALOT of dishes accumulated over a week span. I realized that i had to stop and reapply the soap to the sponge when the sponge was no longer saturated with soap, with both hands. I noticed that it was inefficient because i needed the use of both of my hands. This design would solve the soap application to one hand. Once the soap saturation on the sponge is down to a minimum. I would simply need to place the sponge in the receptacle and slightly push down, reapplying the soap.Since the contact area of the sponge and the soap is spring loaded the area would return to its original position. NOTE: 1) The design is based on a 20 FL OZ bottle and a regular sized sponge (6.25"x3.5").
2) The springs can be found in McMaster Carr catalog PN# 1986K3
or similar substitute.

description.text: This carousal  kitchen utensil and napkin holder makes a nice and neat portable way to store your plastic/silver knives, forks,spoons and napkins. Each type of utensil has its own compartment. The metal holders inside each compartment are covered with a durable foam that not only locks utensils in place;it is also the perfect drying rack. To obtain a utensil simply push the top nob to spin the carousal to your desired utensil. Then turn the gear to raise the utensils so it is within reach.

This was made with Tinkercad. The entire piece is one cylinder with 4 smaller octagon cylinders which made the holes(utensil compartments) and 1 square box for the napkin hole(compartment). The gears were added copy and past from the Tinkercad community list and the nob placed on top. A Tinkercad ring was added beneath the cylinder, re sized to represent the carousal around the bottom.

This is a filament oiler and dust filter made for the Robo3D.  Part of it extends through the slot in the plastic shell to avoid the problem of the filament abrading a groove into the shell as it feeds (see picture).  Add a piece of sponge and some oil and it's ready to go.

I probably don't need to go into much detail here.  
I like to fold a small piece of sponge in half around a piece of filament, then push the sponge in through the top of the filter.  After removing the filament piece, there will be a cavity in the sponge to feed spooled filament through.  
I usually add 0.15 ml of Canola oil to the sponge with a syringe, but I'm sure a few drops is just as good.  
It doesn't hurt to put a little oil or grease on the wear surfaces of the oiler and the printer case.

Stark Spice-O-Matic v0.9 #CountertopChallenge Introducing the Stark Spice-O-Matic! Simply slide the front selector knob to the desired spice, then rotate the side wheel to the desired quantity, thus charging an internal spring. As the spring-wheel unwinds, delicious spices are deposited into the hopper via worm-gear driven augers. This design requires a cheap metal rod with keyway and Bronze Key, as well as one One-Way bearing, and 2 normal bearings. Check the included solidworks files for additional specs. NOTES: Sadly I wasn't able to completely finish this design in time. Remaining tasks include:
  • Add the spring coil.
  • Add two gears to complete the power linkage between the coil and the worm-gear drive bar.
  • Add an internal platform to support the Spice Hoppers.
    • All in all, I'm pretty pleased with this design, and will likely continue to tweak it in the future. But for now, this is my submission, such as it is.

A small Lazy Susan spice rack for the #CountertopChallenge  
It uses 2 CDs for the revolving mechanism.

You will need the following: 2 CDs
glue or double-sided tape
A threaded bolt 1/2" long or slightly longer with a thread diameter of 1/4" or less
A corresponding nut
2 washers (optional but recommended) Print in ABS or PLA at 15% infill. The base and top need to be printed with a diameter of 6 inches. The base is 1/4" high and the top is 1/2" high. If you want a lazy susan without a lip on the edge, just print another base, instead of the top. The large indentation is for the CDs. Glue or tape the label side of the CD to the indentation. The shiny side of the CDs are facing each other when the top and base are put together. Run the bolt through the center hole and tighten. The CDs are very low friction and will allow the spice rack to rotate without the use of ball bearings. Load it up with your favorite spices and hot sauces and enjoy!

What happens when you have a Nesspreso coffee machine but there's no capsule with your favourite coffee flavour? or if you just want to save some money with larger coffee packages? or you just want to do a little recycling?
NesCycler is the answer!!A simple gadget that helps you empty, clean, refill and seal your capsules! NesCycler is fully printed in 3D with makerbot or any other 3D printer.It's easy! Just follow this 4 simple steps: 1 - Press and rotate the capsule in the cleaning part. 2 - Refill the capsule with the desired coffee and compress it with the pressing tool. 3 - Put a piece of aluminium paper over the capsule and cut it with the cutting tool. 4 - Seal the capsule by pressing the two lateral parts. Simple! right?
You have your new refilled capsule to enjoy any coffee you want with your marvelous machine. With some practice you could do the whole process in less than a minute! NesCycler, by Roger Comas

description.text: The purpose of this device is to dispense predetermined amounts of drink mix, such as: hot chocolate, sugar, or powdered flavoring. It includes the choice of three different sizes: small, medium, and large. There are three design options. The first is fully manual; a knob is rotated to release the powder. The second uses a servo to control the knob and three LED's to indicate the amount of powder that will be dispensed. This option uses two buttons to control the desired size, either small, medium, large, or unlimited. Holding the button allows the unlimited feature to be utilized, releasing powder until the button is released. The third option uses an LCD screen to indicate the desired size choice, along with the status of the servo motor: either "in progress" or "ready". It also uses two buttons in the same way as the second option: to choose the desired size. The stand and hopper can easily be recreated and modified based on the individuals preferences based on the dispensers dimensions. Here is a video of the Servo working with the LCD Screen and the two push buttons. https://youtu.be/Bb2jCJ9-6Tw

Depending on your own preferences, either of the three models can be used by downloading their corresponding parts. Manual Model:
-Dispenser
-Dispenser Hopper
-Dispenser Stand
-Dispenser Key Without Servo LED Display Model:
-Dispenser
-Dispenser Hopper
-Dispenser Stand
-Dispenser Key With Servo
-Dispenser Control Panel for LEDs
-Powder_Dispenser_LED.ino LCD Display:
-Dispenser
-Dispenser Hopper
-Dispenser Stand

What's for dinner? For me, in this case, it'll be a stir fry with beef, broccoli, bell peppers, bok choy all in a classic stir fry sauce. It was determined randomly given chosen parameters of my liking. That's right! It's a meal randomizer! Choose a main category and five sub-categories and let What's for Dinner? make the rest of the decisions. An example would be pasta. Okay, what kind of pasta, sauce, veggies, etc.? Come up with all of the possibilities based on your and your dinner mates preferences, put the tokens in the removable cartridges and pull the sliders slowly until one token from each category is freed from the base, lift What's for Dinner? base to reveal the ingredients and cook. No arguments, no fuss about what's for dinner.  
Thanks for looking!  
Included with this set are the tokens for a random stir fry (because I make a lot of stir fry). This set is denoted by the wok handle on the cartridges. So, I know when I pick up a cartridge from this set it's for stir fry. However, one could make different cartridges and tokens for a bunch of randomizations. I'm working on cartridges and tokens for a sandwich randomizer because sandwiches are begging to be randomized and, further, are yummy.

All parts printed at 15% infill and .2mm layer height.  
I did have to use some model glue to hold in the brackets to the base and, in retrospect, I would have tightened up the tolerances on the the release mechanism in so far as the gap in the base goes.

title: Lava Lamp salad dressing dispenser: Groovy!!!

description.text: Lava Lamp salad dressing dispenser

vote for it on the first build site!
https://firstbuild.com/lucaeale2/lava-lamp-salad-dressing-dispenser-groovy/ Now you can serve your raspberry vinaigrette in the grooviest possible way. this is a salad dressing dispenser shaped like the 70's classic.
It includes a LED light for the real lava lamp effect. it uses the 'guts' of a $1 orzak led flash light from walmart, and the rest was designed with sketchup, sliced with slicer and printed on a printrbot simple.
the top screws on/off to add the vinegar and oil for the vinagrette.
Drop a spoon of baking soda form the top, to enjoy the classic "lava" blobs.
Technically, this a "fizz-lamp" rather than a true lava lamp, since it is the CO2 released from the acid-base reaction that brings up the vinegar, which than floats down due to its higher density, rather than the heat expanding the wax like in the lava lamps. the battery pack is a remix from the AAA "Flexing battery holder" from Enif http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456900 it can be used as a salad-dressing dispenser (with oil and vinegar or balsamic vinegar) or just as a lamp. if it is left empty, it works like a camping lamp.
you can use it just with colored water (instead of vinegar) and oil, but in that case you need to drop in alka-seltzer tablet (providing both acid and base) rather than just baking soda, to obtain the lava effect

there are 5 pieces to the print:
  • cap, body, base, battery pack and light holder
    all of them fit in a10x10x10cm volume (we have a printrbot simple)
    the body of the lamp is in clear PLA.
    we printed it as a vase with 2 walls. it has to be water-tight, so the thickness is a concern. what works for you depends on the printer/settings you are using.
    the screw cap is very tight, you might want to print it slightly larger to allow a bit more tolerance
    Once i had all the printed pieces, i gutted the little $1 Ozark led flashlight (http://www.walmart.com/ip/Generic-5026-Ozark-Trail-9-LED-Mini-Flashlight/34350005)
    i used the on/off switch and the 9-led light. i also used the 3 AAA batteries.
    i assembled the base-lamp part as illustrated in the pictures.
    • enjoy!!!!

remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Metal Locking Extruder Handle

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Locking Extruder Handle V2

description.text:
This Locking Extruder Handle is a Refined version of my first Printrbot Simple Metal Locking Extruder Handle http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:651391 which locks in both the open position (to feed in new filament) and the closed position (locked down and ready to print). ALL THE PARTS OF THE NEW VERSION ARE COMPATIBLE WITH THE ORIGINAL VERSION! SO YOU CAN PRINT AND MIX AND MATCH AS YOU PLEASE! New Features:
  • Lock and Unlock symbols on top
  • Fancy "printrbot" label on the front
  • Extended back (so its sits up against the Extruder Stepper Motor)
  • Grill vents on the front to allow ventilation for the aluminum holding the hot end (looks cool if nothing else)
  • Redesigned lever. Made to be stronger than the original one but take up less space.
  • A little aesthetic cleanup

*NOTE: DO NOT ATTEMPT TO PRINT THE ASSEMBLY .stl FILE

  • Print the Extruder Handle Base with the "printrbot" face down.

  • Print the Lever for your handle. Print with support under the over hang. Do not rotate and try to print any other direction. It is aligned to give you the most strength.

  • Print the little Connector.

  • Assemble the Handle with three M3 20mm screws, (same ones used on the simple metal, I got mine from my kits leftovers).

  • Print a Dust Filter for your handle. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:492067 I highly suggest printing one for each spool you have so that you do not have to monkey with getting filament through the filter each time. And, they don't take long to print anyway! :)

  • Slide on to your Simple Metal. You will have to lift up the upper part of the base to get it to line up with the angle of the aluminum extruder arm. May take a little wiggling. Wiggling is good though! It means it fits snug!

  • Post a Picture! :)

title: Material Roll Holder with Cutter for Convenient Mounting

description.text:
Not only does this material holder allow for straight tearing of tin foil, wax paper, or plastic wrap, but it mounts great on the back of a cabinet door or on the back of your pantry door. It even works when mounted both vertically or horizontally!
It mounts perfectly with Command strips for a mess free installation but also has small divots for drilling if you so choose to use short screws. After initial assembly and setup, loading a new roll is surprisingly simple.
Unhook the rubber bands from the roll supporting rod and place around the the protruding arm.
Remove the empty material roll.
Pull up the left side of the material retaining rod. (The rod on top of the material with an open yet snug slot on the left side)
Replace the material roll with the inserted roll supporting rod.
Re-hook the rubber bands back around the roll supporting rod for tension.
Pull some material over the cutter rod.
Re-insert the material tension rod by inserting into the right hole which is came from and firmly press the left end into the open slot.
(It's actually easier and faster than it sounds)

Aside from printing the right and left roll holders, you will need to print 3 of the roll cutters. Being that most material rolls are 12 inches long, I made each cutter piece 4 inches long to be printable on most machines. You will also need some 3/8" dowel rod.
--Two 12.75" long and one 14" long.
Six wood screws (I used #4x1/2" flat heads)
Two rubber bands (length and tension will vary of course)
And two Command strips depending on your chosen mounting method. I used two 5lb strips that were the perfect size of the door/wall facing surface of the end pieces. (see pictures) !NOTICE!
The roll cutter piece was a particular challenge. I printed them at .4mm layer height but checked the extruder path before printing to ensure it was making a single in and out motion per tooth in order to print the sharpest edge without incurring extra radii. (see pictures) As far as initial assembly goes, the pictures help a lot. Screw the 3 roll cutter pieces into one of the 12.75" dowel rods all seated next to each other and centered. There should be space on both ends of the dowel still. It helps to pre-drill the holes in the rod. I was able to use #4x1/2" screws without having the screws come out the other side of the rod. I would've used smaller screws if I could find them. Wrap the rubber bands around the end pieces. You don't have to do it as pictured but you want just a little tension up where it will hook around the roll supporting rod. Then hooking the other end around the protruding arm is a good place keeper for it. Next put both end pieces onto the cutter rod. My printed holes came out undersized and even after drilling them out, the rod fit snug into the holes which worked perfect for holding everything straight and stable. At this time orient the cutter rod for your preferred cutting angle. (It'll be tight, but you can still tweak that later) Now, with the 14" rod in the material roll, place it onto the holder over the angled arms so that the material would be pulled from under the roll. It should be centered so that material is touching the back of the bracket and the dowel is over hanging on both sides. Then unhook the rubber bands off of the arms and onto the rod so it's pulling downward. This should be lightly tensioned and not loose. Pull the material forward and over the cutter rod. Take the other 12.75" rod and insert one end into the hole just behind the cutter rod in the right end piece. (This hole is supposed to be oversized) Lay the rod down over the material onto the corresponding open slot in the left end piece. It should just lay on top of it. With a firm press, push it down snug into the slot. (Mine had a very nice snap to it) You should also be able to get that end of the rod out of that slot. Ta daa. All that's left to do is mount it where you want. This was my first printing with abs so while I'm happy with the overall design I'm aware my print itself may not be up to par on quality but all the parts preformed as needed.

description.text:
38 mm hanging spool bearing. Materials:
12 mm m3 x 4 1/4 inch countersink bit (to ream the acme rod hole)
C clamp or vice to jam in chain
appropriate pre drill bit for your chain.
2 zip ties incase the plastic de-laminates.

Print out 2 adapters, 2 bearing holders (i just repaired the original and slapped two on the plate for the stl posted here) and 2 chain adapters. I use 1 infil for these because it is hanging above a glass desk. Ream the acme to 608 adapters with the quarter inch countersink. Hold it with something so you dont mangle your hands with the drill, I used pliers .
You might need to file the 608zz surface slightly with a nail file. I like filing you get a better fit if you work at it. I use a dollar store nail file.
Once they fit nice and snugly in the 608zz bearings , make sure your acme bar fits in. One side should be tight , one considerably looser.
Jam your chain in the adapters. I used a 10foot box of chain from standard hw supply. About 34mm x 11mm on each link. I used a drill to slightly widen the hole then a c clamp to jam it in there. Slap a set screw in to lock the chain in so vibration doesnt ruin your day. Slide in the acme bar , lock one set screw and tiewrap it around the chain link and the bar. IF the plastic breaks this will save your day. The other do the same but leave it loose so you can mount spools. It will grip the acme bar and lock it on but I still use a set screw on both sides. It will be a really really bad day to have a 2 lb weight crash into my printer / glass desk. Everything should be tight.

The Compact Kitchen Console is perfect for those who need to maximize the use of their counter top space. It's my entry into the First Build/Thingiverse Countertop Challenge. It includes:
  • Reclining Recipe Book/Tablet stand (30, 45, and 60 degrees)
  • Expandable Platforms for 11.4" of additional counter top space (total horizontal space of up to 22" , resulting in 154 cubic inches of work space)
  • Digital Weighing Scale
  • Digital Kitchen Timer
  • Cuisine Selector (it's like "spin the wheel" for those who can't decide what to eat!)
  • Drawer Compartment
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D8va4W8fm5g

Reclining Recipe Stand
The recipe stand has a kickstand behind it that lets you choose between 30, 45, and 60 degree viewing angles. It can recipe books (big and small), iPads/Tablets, your cellphone, etc. Extendable Platforms
There are two extendable platforms that add 5.71" of table top space each for a total additional counter top space of about 22 inches. There are rotating arms underneath that hold the platforms securely in place so they don't collapse. The platform is about 10" high, so you have plenty of room to put things underneath as well! This way, the Compact Kitchen Console doesn't take up a very large foot print on your counter top. Digital Weighing Scale
The weighing scale has a weight capacity of 6.6 lbs and can measure as little as 0.1 oz. It uses a load cell to measure weight. Digital Kitchen Timer
The kitchen timer has stopwatch and countdown functions so you can keep track of how long your food is cooking. "Spin The Wheel" Cuisine Selector"
The "Spin The Wheel" Cuisine Selector lets you write down your favorite types of food and then give it a quick spin to see what it lands on. I've found myself pacing around the room for 2 whole hours trying to figure out what to eat (no joke, don't judge!). Hopefully this will fix that! Drawer Storage Compartment
Lastly, there is a storage compartment underneath. If the Compact Kitchen Console is in a central area, it may be a convenient place to put a post-it note grocery list, your rings (while cooking), or anything else you want quick access to in the kitchen.

Collapsed: 10" wide x 7" deep x 11" tall
Fully expanded with recipe stand completely upright: 22" long x 7" deep by 18" tall.
Counter top foot print: 5.7" L x 5.2" W
~1.2 kg (2.65 lb) of PLA

The STL files are already oriented the way they should be printed.   
If you have specific questions, please post a comment! I can also upload instructional pictures upon request.

Print with the settings of your choice. I used MakerBot Desktop's PLA LOW RESOLUTION settings*: Layer Height: 0.3mm
Infill: 10%
Rafts: NO
Supports: YES (not everything will require supports, but this setting ensures MakerBot Desktop will add them when necessary) *The exception to this is Build Plate #5: LCD Panel Faceplate. Print this one in STANDARD resolution or better (0.2mm layer height). I discovered that printing in low resolution would not allow the weighing scale's LCD to be screwed securely in place.

Some of the parts are quite large, so there is a risk of warping/curling (even with PLA plastic). I recommend you apply Blue Painter's tape DIAGONALLY on your build plate, NOT horizontally (see picture). The diagonal orientation makes a huge difference, and is how I got all my parts to print very flat.

Since the LCD Panel's back plate may be too long to fit some printers (I was have the original Replicator Dual which has a maximum build length of 220mm), the back plate is cut in half. On the same build plate, there is a connector piece that joins the two halves together and holds them in place without the need for glue.

Just like the LCD Panel's back plate, the Front plate is also cut in half. The connector piece printed on this build plate will join them together. Before joining the pieces, please remember to insert the cylindrical rod and octagon shaped object from Build Plate #9 into this face plate. Those two pieces make the Cuisine Selector work!  
Additionally, you'll notice this build plate has a piece that holds the Timer's circuit board in place. I had to borrow some screws from the Weighing Scale to screw this into place. Be careful not to screw it in too tightly or there won't be enough room for the Timer's buttons to be clickable.

description.header: PINS and CONNECTORS from Build Plate #9:
description.text:
The long pins fit in the hinges that connect the extendable platforms. The shorter pins (all the same size) go everywhere else.
The kickstand does not need pins. Instead, just insert 1.75mm 3D printing filament (I recommend PLA) and it works perfectly! The cylindrical pole and octagon shaped object fit into the LCD faceplate (Build Plate #6) to make the Cuisine Selector work.

I used dual color printing via the MakerBot Replicator 1 Dual to print the buttons on the LCD Panel. As you'll see with the attached STL files, you don't need to do this. The single color buttons have the appropriate text engraved already.

The load cell and LCD were removed from: http://www.amazon.com/Taylor-Compact-Digital-Scale-Red/dp/B00J963J6S The kitchen timer components were removed from: http://www.amazon.com/Taylor-5842-21-Mini-Digital-Timer/dp/B006TG4QL8 The housing for all of the circuity was completely re-designed from scratch so it would fit as one panel. Additionally, I created a custom battery pack within the LCD panel to hold 3 AAA batteries. Two of the batteries are in series and supply 3V to the weighing scale, and the remaining battery supplies 1.5V to the kitchen timer.

I have uploaded a "SOURCE FILES ZIP" that includes:
+The original Blender file used to design everything
+All the individual STL files in case you want to print a specific part rather than use my pre-made build plates on thingiverse

Cantilevered 600mm CNC-cut stool from 18mm ply  
It is purely glued and doweled, there are no metal fastenings.

Cut from 1/2 sheet of 18mm Ply and 6x 270mm 10mm hardwood dowels.  
Place one full-length piece down on a flat surface, glue and install all dowel pieces.  
Alternate top and bottom pieces and spacers, glueing all meeting faces and dowels. Finish with full-length piece.  
Clamp until glue is dry.  
Alternatively, glue and clamp in top/bottom pairs and do final assembly when glue is set.  
The key to a successful stool is at the face join and two dowels in the centre of the stool - that is where all the stresses reside. Get those joints right with glue, dowels and clamping and you will have a solid piece of furniture.  Don't scrimp on quality or amount of glue. I use Titebond II Premium and it is perfect, clean up excess with a damp cloth while clamping.  
I finish my outside edges with a 1/4" roundover router bit and sand till smooth, then apply an oil/varnish finish and use felt or nylon buffers on the bottom.  
I use Meranti plywood - it doesn't need to be furniture grade, as the layout has the two end pieces in mirror-image, so you can pick the best side as the outer, display face. I like Meranti over Baltic Birch or Pine ply as the colour is richer and the grain is more pronounced, but whatever works for you.   
Don't use MDF - it's too heavy and will chip easily. I'm not convinced it will be strong enough, long-term. The ply plus dowel gives 'bounce' and feels more comfortable.  
You can top with an upholstered pad, if you want. I have an alternative version with a cut-out for insetting a leather pad. Ask if you are interested in the model.  
Completed, varnished and with protection on the bottom, these retail for $1600-2000 a set of 4, depending on finish.  
If you want to commercially reproduce them, licensing is very reasonable - contact the designer.

title: Differential Gear 2.1 / 3.0 & 3.1 (education)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This thingy was made with Tinkercad - for printing download the 1 to 5 part files.
VIDEO HERE -> https://1drv.ms/v/s!AqWl4jx0O11ayFBHNlaNiPQswj1f
AND HERE -> https://1drv.ms/v/s!AqWl4jx0O11ayE8D-vZ4plPWN9V1 Note: the screenshots are from earlier version 1.0 and 2.0... 3.0 will be publisched besides 2.1 (taken apart version with minor tweaks) DONE !!! STL has been checked. See pictures for parts included. A needed thingy will follow. Yep it was the table (cut it as you like)
https://tinkercad.com/things/fnBhTWrLgTx From all the parts some need to be glued, others need Duct Tape. Advise "don't glue the wrong ones together". TinkerCad is a simple but very educational tool for kids and grownups. No installation needed and sharing your design has been made extremely easy. So it's the ideal setup for kids in a learning environment exploring and understanding the world of technology and combining hystory lessons with practical computer lessons and making them familiar with 3D printing. Have fun... The model is designed in such a way, so that it can be assembled from loose parts. You wil need two ty-rips to hold the housing together. Most of the object is made out of simple solids. Only the gears were to complex so they had to be made in Autodesk Creative Platform using Java Script. I edited an existing code set some values to integer, which made it much more stable. the code now also allows 2 side bevel choice and helix in both directions. The reason I choose to make a differential, was because I bought a miniature truck (1:16) for my son, but it was almost impossible for him to make a turn with it. The wheels were fixed and so the friction of the rather large wheels prevented the truck from turning. (see picture) If you would like to edit the TinkerCad file check out:
Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/h6qCLJCYrTg file version 2.0 had a few corrections
  • forgot to group some holes in the green drive gear
  • it's axis had minor cosmetical problems
    • file version 2.1 has 2 different things to do
  • group (fixed)
  • axis (fixed
  • locked in gears / can't take apart (fixed)
  • take apart and make easily printable (agenda, when I feel like it)

As mentioned this was made in TinkerCad most actions:
  • Align
  • Hollow / Color
  • Group

title: Another View
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I would rather have radioactive material in my backyard (literally, a neighborhood nuclear reactor) and put up with the tiny chance of harm than have coal fired power plants continue to emit unbelievable amounts of the powerful neurotoxin known best as mercury which has thus contaminated the majority of open bodies of water in the US. One day logic and reason will prevail over ignorance; until then, people will continue to believe John Lennon wasn't an egotistical hypocrite and that nuclear power is dangerous.
This model was derived from Schorhr's earring #50 and Nophead's heart shaped box.

This is untested since the PTFE leads on my hot end gave out. Print and look up some mortality statistics, then balk at the fact that you are way more likely to die in a car accident or by falling than any other accident, Especially terrorists or radiation from a failed nuclear power plant. The great thing about facts is that they aren't changed by opinions.

comments.text: Neither coal nor nuclear power is a solution. While I do understand your concerns, the also dangerous alternative  should not be something that you automaticaly "love".
comments.author: Schorhr

comments.text: I've read through two overviews of the epidemiological data (http://www.nirs.org/radiation/radhealth/kikkcommentary0709ijoeh.pdfhttp://www.nirs.org/radiation/... and http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2696975/http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pm... ), specifically regarding the KiKK study, and the conclusions are that even with a statistically significant increase in risk of developing leukemia for kids under 5 and within 5 Km of a NPP there is no demonstration of a causal relationship. Indeed, it is not even known what causes leukemia. As one paper says, "Based on the findings of radiation research such a connection seems implausible, because the radiation emitted by an NPP in normal operation is at least 1000 times lower than "background radiation," i.e., the 1.4 mSv of natural radiation to which the average German is exposed in a year."
comments.author: Schorhr

comments.text:
&
gt; this stuff comes from the environment to begin with
comments.author: dreameredeemer

comments.text: That's a good point regarding mercury, the main difference being that coal power plants are allowed to always emit mercury whereas nuclear power plants are required to contain the radiation as much as possible.
comments.author: Schorhr

comments.text:
Then let's just agree that we need cheap
&
amp; printable renewable energy devices, and let's both get back to work :-)

description.text: The perfect, easy way to keep those irritating power cords organized.

Made this arm out of PLA plastic using sketchup, Made up of 7 Hitec 645MG Servos and 1 Hitec 85MG servo for the gripper, At full length it can only pick up about 200 grams but half way in it can pick up about 500 grams thanks to the dual servo at 2nd and 3rd DOF. The arm is still a work inprogress Added SKP Files for people who want to tinker. https://youtu.be/ThECL_-q7jg

Printed parts:
2 x of the arm1 part1
2 x of the arm1 part2
5 x of the servo arm brackets
5 x of the gripper part1
2 x gripper ends rest one print of each Extra thing that you will need to make this: 1 x 100mm square lazy susan bearing
5 x 5x8x2.5mm Flanged Bearings AXIA1214 MF85-ZZ
M3 Bolts 10, 12, 20, 25, 30, 40, 50mm
10 x M3 10mm counter sunk bolts for servo brackets
M3 Locking Nuts
8mm M2 needle servo screws
20mm and (35mm for base plate) nylon hex M3 standoffs
Plus 7 (hitec) Standard servos Metal Gear recommended
1 micro servo Metal Gear recommended still working on a better rotor base its abit hard to screw the middle servo in but it can be done.

comments.text: Hmm... Looking at this, it brings back memories of when our robot would start to fall apart mid-match. And we definitely wished we had an onboard arm, just to hold that one bolt in place before it fell out that one piece of 80/20. It didn't actually fall out, but the frame was shaking loose. Hopefully we can put a few of these arms onboard this year.

title: Smaller 70% Lightsaber Based on ROTJ Artoo Throwing Model - 5 part

description.text: This was designed for my lightsaber thrower, YouTube of my experimentation with it at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q97qotXkA6k - Launcher is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:792506 I needed a not-full-scale lightsaber without being particularly particular. I also needed a hole down the middle for a shaft. If you want a full-size and more accurate saber, look at my take on the Obi-Wan Kenobi version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:626171 I intend to use this with L3-G0 the full size Lego R2-D2 Support my things please :)
I made this 70.7% size lightsaber to go with my full size, working Lego R2-D2 - http://L3-G0.com - Check out L3-G0's YouTube Videos.

I used a couple different models, but neither worked exactly. This isn't "perfect", but one model seemed pretty far off. I compared it to pictures of the stunt saber Luke caught from R2-D2 in Return of the Jedi. http://www.partsofsw.com/jedsab_2.htm has some info about it. I printed it all on Medium, .2mm layer height, on a replicator 1 clone. I used supports only for the switch part (part 9), which I printed on it's end. One of the "part 1" pommel bits has no hole if you prefer that. The original switch I copied also seems short, so I made a "tall" version that may be preferred. My print weight < 1.5oz/40g I intend to use this with L3-G0, my full size Lego R2-D2 - https://youtu.be/PmXUBGq_uiU Support my things please :)

author: kresty

description.text: Unfortunately with the recent change in Thingiverse's policy of model ownership I am moving all of my models to my own file services found at http://www.farvew.com the link can be found toward the bottom of the page. This antenna has been revised and thus outdated, this is the link to the latest revision: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:798650 If you don't have a CNC Mill, the materials or soldering skills, I am producing these and other antennas here on my web page: http://farvew.com/

I based the design of of a couple of popular versions that are out online, I also love the RG402 coax because of how easy it is to work with. Things required:
  • One Sided PCB 1.5mm thick by 52mm wide (Templates are included for the round reflector and octagonal)
  • RG402 Coax cable
  • 2mm copper cable (standard yellow home wiring if you live in the USA)
  • Hot glue or CA
    • Instructions:
  • Start by using the former to wind your copper wire into the desired shape. (Note that the former is slightly smaller than the desired diameter, it should spring back slightly after its wound)
  • Cut out your reflector.
  • Slide the reflector in place be sure to keep track of where you put the lead hole.
  • Slide the frame together and start feeding the coil down from the top.
  • Strip back the shielding/ braid of the RG402 so you have about 1.5mm of the inner conductor visible
  • Solder the shielding/ braid of the RG402 to the copper reflector ( Not much is needed but for strength it is a good idea to get as much covered as possible)
  • Solder the inner conductor to the copper wire, you need a two millimeter gap between the wire and the reflector plate.
  • Use a multimeter to make sure it is not grounded and you are all good to go!

description.text: Something new and different for mice to chew on...

This stand confuses mice. Here's my cool story (bro).
Last Spring I spied one rather large, fat little mouse. Suspecting it was a pregnant female intent on raising pups in my space, I wanted her gone as quickly as possible.
Tried everything (except poison). Various tilt traps.. electronic-zapper.. spring killers... constructed a water-bucket gizmo.. Live-catch cages. Glue-traps.
Nothing worked. This was one smart mouse, wise to all of mankind's deceptions.
A week passed and I saw this mouse about once a day. Even midday... showed no fear. I was worried, and needed something she had never seen before. At last, inspiration struck. Originally, I took a couple of these spring traps, and taped them up against a wall, with masking tape to hold them. Another was against a cardboard box. Within hours, she was history. And having nipped it in the bud, I was mouse-free for a year. Bait and place it as you normally would.
Sprinkle a few grains of Quaker Oats or some other dry, boring breakfast cereal (won't go moldy or attract insects) at the base, in case it's too stupid to raise its head and look up, and walks past it.
Reaching up for food is not normal, which is why this stand is effective. Also, vertical traps are close to the wall, less liable to be accidentally tripped, and easier to sweep around. I'd be interested in anyone's experiences using a vertical trap. My success may have been a fluke, but I don't think so.

title: Soap Saver - Insert for soap trays that keeps soap drier so it lasts longer and minimizes mess
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Soap trays usually have drains and/or contoured bases to try and keep the underside of a block of soap dry as damp soap is soft soap and soft soap washes away very quickly... not to mention leaving lots of soapy 'gunk' in the bottom of the tray.   
The 'Soap Saver' is designed to be used in any existing soap tray... not instead of the tray. It holds the bar of soap in the air upright or on its side. It also angles backwards so it almost doesn't have any 'underside' surface area as the underside is the area that commonly stays damp... which makes a mess... and washes away very quickly during the next use.    .   
Most soap trays are made to try and keep soap dry underneath but few if any really do... the underside always stays damp regardless of drains and contours. This solves that issue...  
Even bars of soap that are formed with a curve soon revert to having flat sides so suffer from the dampness, stay soft and wash away easily as a result. If you want drier longer lasting soap and less mess in your soap trays print some of these...  
If you like this take time to check out my other designs!
Print with Raft, standard resolution (0.20mm), 4 shells and 35% infill to make is sufficiently strong and durable.

description.text: Have you ever needed a spear to hunt grizzly bears? Well now you can make one for $2! ( DO NOT ATTEMPT TO HUNT GRIZZLY BEARS ) I bought a 10 ' section of 1/2" pvc for $1.80 at my local Home Depot and this spear head cost about 27 cents (depending on the cost of your filament). For some reason when i load my files i've made into repetier the scale is all messed up, So if this happens to you i scaled my part by  12-13 for a snug fit (glue you wish).

1) download and print the file (may need support and requires a fan for optimal printing. May also require a brim depending on your printer. I printed with 50% infil.)
2) Buy a 1/2" pvc pipe of any length desired, I made mine with a 4" pipe .
3) Insert the spear head base into the pvc pipe, sanding may be required.
4) Glue the spear head into the pipe (optional) i left mine friction fit, that way if the spear head were to break i could easily replace it.
5) Have fun impaling boxes or what ever else you would do with this. Be careful with this as it could hurt sombody, i am not responsible for injury, death, mauling via grizzly bear, or any other user/bystander accedents. HAVE FUN!!!

Disclaimer: I did not design this. Will, a commentator on my blog ( http://makerblock.com/2011/03/can-we-make-a-printed-nerf-dart-shooter/#comments ) , left a link to this page ( http://nerfhaven.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=20819 ) at Nerfhaven.com where a member named SorrowX uploaded pictures, design files, and STL's for his rapid prototyped Nerf Blaster. I've uploaded the STL's here. I suspect these parts will be way oversized to allow printing on a MakerBot. However, I'm hopeful others can build on SorrowX's excellent work.

comments.text: VERY nice work.  I was messing around and I think I have a variation that's worth a build.  Have you had much luck with solenoids?  I've tried compressed air and it seems to be shredding darts.
comments.author: sorrowx

comments.text: Solenoids are good for for this type of application, as well as compressed air. However, there is a variety of reasons your darts are shredding with it. First off, Stock darts are crap, and are no good for high-pressure applications. I recommend using homemade darts called stefans. easy and cheap to make. Second, your barrel might not be the best one for your applications. CPVC and PEX tubing are good for spring guns for their tight fit. with air, you want a looser fit of PETG found here: http://modmansnerfhardware.auctivacommerce.com/Barrels-C221417.aspx?sid=21391http://modmansnerfhardware.auc... hope that helps!

description.text: New version - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1697237 The mount is designed around my LG G2 in an Incipio case. Modify the clips for other applications. The pieces were printed in PLA at .2 mm layer height and 100% density. The center mount piece is tapped with M3 threads. Printed pieces hold threads surprisingly well. M3x25 socket head screws hold the clips to the center piece. An M4x45 flat head screw holds the mount to the transmitter bracket. A nut secures the bolt to one side of the arm. I'm not entirely sure it was necessary but I didn't want the screw turning. The well in the thumb screw holds an M4 nut. iris_phone_bracket1a.stl has a simple bracket with a shorter thumb screw. title: Kia grand carnival 2010 interior light swtch modification

description.text:
A switch modification for a Kia grand carnival 2010 interior light, to stop my 2 year old from playing with it ( well hopefuly )  
Update: it worked she stopped playing with it, not more flat batteries.

1). Need to remove the interior light from roof of car by the screws highlighted
![alt text]( http://3dthings.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/image.jpg ) 2). Next we need to disconnect the White plug and the whole unit can be removed from the car.
![alt text]( http://3dthings.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/image1.jpg ) 3). To remove the switch slider, we need to bend up the two little Metal tabs and pull out the plastic slide.
![alt text]( http://3dthings.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/image2.jpg ) 4). with the switch apart we can bend back the metal tabs so it will hold on our replacement slider part, gently squeeze the tabs down using a pair of pliers.
![alt text]( http://3dthings.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/image3.jpg ) 5). with your newly printed slider just insert it where the one on came out and place the metal contacts on top. then gently walk it down by pushing a little one side and the the other.
![alt text](http://3dthings.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/image4-e1426418682546.jpg )
Until it's all the way to the bottom.
![alt text]( http://3dthings.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/image5.jpg ) That's it!!! Just reinstall it and You're are done!!!

title: Airsoft silencer protective cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a protective cap for airsoft dummy silencers.
All of new guns have one cap to protect the top of the cannon, for protect it and safe use.

I made two versions (because i found that there are one silencer with 30mm diameter and another with 32).
My silencer have a diameter of 31,4mm, so i think the 32mm protective is for me. The inner diameter of the cap is 31mm and 33mm respectively, and i add eight 0,5mm inner guides to fit it better (So, the real inner diameter are 30,5mm and 32,5mm). Its height is 4cm. Edit1- My silencer have a diameter of 31mm, so the 32mm fit a little loose (fixed it with a little heat). I will try the 30mm version. Edit2- The 30mm cap doesnt fit into my 31mm silencer (logical), so i heated with a small burner my 32mm version and push a little to make a small inner bump, and it works! Edit3- Added a 34mm version, with inner diameter of 35,4mm.

author: Nuxeretes

description.text: I made this customized card holder by working off the Gnome one found on thingiverse!

I used these to clip on some LED strip lights to the top three struts of my Kossel Mini. They leave about 1.5mm room, perfect for LED Strips with hard PCB base.  
It is best to make multiple of them to give each layer enough time to cool down, and keep the printer busy while waiting.  
They require some force to put on the extrusions but they will not fall off. They can slide around on the extrusion though, when the room between the extrusion and the part isn't completely filled.  
Designed in SketchUp
